PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Earnings including GrainCorp, Korea Gas, Rakuten and Sony
content:
AUSTRALIA

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. April Caltex Refiner Margin USD 4.83/bbl vs. Prev. USD 4.62/bbl M/M. (Newswires)

Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Co. guides FY21 to return to positive oper. profit and cashflow, while it confirmed credit facilities with National Australia Bank. (Newswires)

GrainCorp (GNC AT) - Co. HY net AUD 388.3mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 58.9mln Y/Y, HY rev. rose 3.4% to AUD 1.96bln, does not propose to pay an interim dividend for the half-year. (Newswires)

New Hope Corporation (NHC AT) - Co. COO Boyd is viewed to be the most likely successor following retirement of MD Stepan. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. announces hiring for more than 300 positions in Australia. (Newswires)

Senex Energy (SXY AT) - Co. signs new 1-year gas sales agreement with CleanCo Queensland. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Coca-Cola Bottlers Japan (2579 JT) - Co. Q1 net loss JPY 5.7bln vs. Prev. loss JPY 8.0bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

East Japan Railway (9020 JT) - Co. will reduce high-speed bullet train service by 40% indefinitely from May 28th. (Nikkei)

Fuji Media Holdings (4676 JT) - C. FY net JPY 41.3bln vs. Prev. JPY 23.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. plans to reduce it workforce in Thailand and has offered workers early retirement. (Newswires)

Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding (7003 JT) - Co. sold around JPY 100bln of operations and assets. (Newswires)

Nexon (3659 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 49.9bln vs. Prev. JPY 53.4bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Rakuten (4755 JT) - Co. Q1 net loss JPY 35.3bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 104.8bln Y/Y, Rakuten Mobile unit plans to acquire Innoeye to support its communications platform. (Newswires)

Shinsei Bank (8303 JT) - Co. FY pretax profit JPY 51.0bln vs. Prev. JPY 55.4bln Y/Y, will repurchase up to 8.9% of shares for JPY 20.5bln. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 582.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 916.3bln Y/Y, confirms PS5 on track to launch this holiday season and will not provide specific guidance for FY 20/21 due to coronavirus. (Newswires)

Subaru (7270 JT) - Co. is seeking JPY 60bln in loans from Mizuho and Development Bank of Japan. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Dainippon Pharma (4506 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 40.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 48.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan government plans to inject capital into companies negatively impacted by the coronavirus. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Daewoo Engineering & Construction (047040 KS) - Co. awarded KRW 478bln contract for Nigeria LNG plant. (Newswires)

Hanmi Pharmaceutical (128940 KS) - Co. said Sanofi wants to return the rights related to diabetes treatment. (Newswires)

Korean Air Lines (003490 KS) - Co. is to raise KRW 1tln through share sales. (Yonhap)

Korea Gas (036460 KS) - Co. Q1 net KRW 541.9bln vs. Prev. KRW 532.3bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea targets the creation of 1.5mln jobs in the public sector. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US COVID-19 cases rose 1.5% to 1,364,061 (Prev. +1.4%) and death toll rose 1.8% to 82,246 (Prev. +1.3%). (Newswires)

US President Trump said the US surpassed 10mln virus tests, while he thinks the US should reopen schools and that the virus has little effect on young people. Furthermore, President Trump said he was surprised by Dr. Fauci’s comments regarding risks of reopening too soon which is not an acceptable answer and that Fauci wants to play both sides of the equation, while he also suggested that the House stimulus bill is dead on arrival. (Newswires)

NJ Governor Murphy took steps towards a reopening of the economy citing declines in the coronavirus spread, while he stated that non-essential construction and retail pick up can start on May 18th. Elsewhere, Washington DC announced it is extending its stay at home restrictions until June 8th from May 15th and LA County issued a new stay at home order with no end date specified. (Newswires/LA Times)

German Interior Minister said Germany, France and Austria have agreed to ease border controls from May 16th. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

China’s Cabinet said it will step-up macroeconomic adjustments to offset the impact of COVID-19 and will prioritise employment, energy security, supply chain sustainability, as well as social welfare and grains. There were also comments from the head of the NDRC that they will utilise RRR cut, interest rate cuts and re-lending to keep liquidity at reasonably ample levels. (Newswires)

Chinese economists suggested China could set its GDP growth target at 3% in its Two Sessions event next week and may set a two-year GDP target for 2020/21 instead of just a single one for each year. (Global Times)

China will soon impose countermeasures on US individuals and entities filing lawsuits seeking COVID-19 damages from China according to sources, while US states suing China are highly likely to face business and trade consequences. (Global Times)

US President Trump extended the executive order protecting the US supply chain from Huawei and ZTE for an additional year, according to a statement. (Newswires)

US retirement investment board has delayed the transition of USD 40bln international fund to track the MSCI index including controversial Chinese Co's, according to a statement which cited COVID-19 and new board nominations as being behind the delay. (Newswires)

A National Security Official told CNBC's Javers there is concern China may try to keep the US from getting a vaccine. (CNBC)

 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Bailey said he hopes fiscal authorities will consider all choices and that the BoE can help spread the cost out of COVID over time, when asked about austerity policies. BoE Governor Bailey also signalled the bank is likely to increase government bond purchases and noted it is pretty clear the markets assumption is that there will be more QE, while he added the latest data confirms we have a very sharp move into a recession. (Newswires/ITV)

ECB's de Guindos expects the eurozone economy to rebound in Q3 and Q4, while he expects growth of 6% in 2021 but noted the level of uncertainty is still very high and that it will take the eurozone two years to fully recover. (Newswires)

ECB, Bundesbank and the German government are reportedly attempting to find a face-saving way to defuse the danger from the GCC ruling on the Euro-Area integrity in which the Bundesbank could write the report or the ECB could but it would not be official. (Die Zeit/Twitter)

EU officials are looking to finalise a plan for public stakes in European companies that are deemed key/strategic, according to sources. Furthermore, one option being mulled is for a "solvency support" scheme" that is funded by member states and another is for companies to issue convertible bonds to the EIB, which would later be converted into equity stakes. (Newswires)

European Parliament's draft resolution said it will not agree to the EU's next long-term budget of 2021-27 unless the EU gets new dedicated sources of revenue. (Newswires)

  • UK GDP (Q1 P Y/Y) -1.6% vs. Exp. -2.1% (Prev. 1.1%). (Newswires)
  • UK GDP Estimate (Mar) Y/Y -5.7% vs. Exp. -7.2% (Prev. 0.3%)
  • UK Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -8.2% vs. Exp. -9.3% (Prev. -2.8%, Rev. -3.4%)
  • UK Manufacturing Production (Mar) Y/Y -9.7% vs. Exp. -10.4% (Prev. -3.9%, Rev. -4.3%)
  • EU Industrial Production (Mar) M/M -11.3% vs. Exp. -12.1% (Prev. -0.1%)
  • EU Industrial Production (Mar) Y/Y -12.9% vs. Exp. -12.4% (Prev. -1.9%, Rev. -2.2%)

 

FX

RBNZ Governor Orr said the NZD 60bln is a limit and not a target for its QE programme, while he also noted that monetary policy will play a role by keeping interest rates low for the foreseeable future. Furthermore, Governor Orr said QE program is the best option for now and that operational challenges still remain for negative interest rates, while he does not rule out direct purchase of government bonds. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -0.745M vs. Exp. 4.147M (Prev. 4.59M). (Newswires)

US DoE is to purchase 1mln bbls of oil from small to mid-size producers for the SPR and stated that the purchases will serve as a test of conditions of the physical crude oil available to the reserve, while it noted the purchase of 1mln bbls is far less than the original plan for up to 30mln bbls. (Newswires)

OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report stated 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down and reiterated the worst contraction expected to take place in Q2. The report showed 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 2.23mln BPD from prior report (Prev. cut of 6.9mln BPD), now forecast at 9.07mln BPD. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia and Russia see signs of a recovery in oil demand and the nations remain firmly committed to achieving market stability, as well as expediting rebalancing of the oil market. Furthermore, they are pleased with recent signs of improvement in economic and market indicators, while Russian Energy Minister Novak said he welcomes the additional oil output cuts from Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)

Iraq said it will bring total cuts to around 700k BPD after agreeing with oil majors to cut production in Southern fields by 300k BPD, according to officials. (Newswires)

FBI is probing Mexican and European firms for allegedly trading Venezuelan oil in violation of US Treasury sanctions, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

US

NY Fed will discontinue three-month repo operations during this monthly period in light of more stable repo market conditions, although it will continue the overnight repo operation once per day and one-month repo operations once per week. Furthermore, it will continue to adjust repo operations as appropriate to support effective policy implementation and the smooth functioning of short-term U.S. dollar funding markets. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell stated that additional policy measures may be needed to avoid lasting damage to the economy and that the Fed will use tools to their "fullest" until the crisis has passed and recovery is well underway. Powell added that he expects unemployment to peak in the next month or so but will remain above levels seen in 2018-19. Furthermore, Powell said FOMC view on negative rates has not changed and it is not looking at negative rates, while he added the Fed intends to continue using tools it has already tried and previous FOMC minutes have indicated "all" participants were against them. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (voter, hawk) said negative rates are not being discussed and there are lots of problems with them, while she added we are in the early days of assessing the risks to the outlook and there is a lot of pain out there. (CNBC)

US President Trump said he likes negative interest rates and feels strongly the US should have negative rates, while he added that despite differences with Fed Chair Powell on negative rates, he feel's Powell's performance as Fed Chair has improved. (Newswires)

  • US PPI Final Demand (Apr) Y/Y -1.2% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Equities endured another down day (ES printed sub 2,800 briefly), and the VIX jumped back higher rising into the 37s, moving out of contango; stock losses attributed to Fed chair Powell pushing back against the idea of negative US rates, and US/China tensions ramping up again ahead of November’s Presidential elections. This downside has not been unexpected; recall, Goldman Sachs on the weekend provided a list of reasons why equities could see downside this week, without a specific headline catalyst (US/China risks were an identified risk); while others have suggested that the bear market rally is now over; that caution has been heard from some very influential investors too. Today, Appaloosa’s Tepper made similar warnings to those of Stan Druckenmiller yesterday, while recent commentary from BlackRock’s Fink and Berkshire Hathaway’s Buffett all seem to be calling into question the potential for large equity upside. The latest Uber (UBER) and Grubhub (GRUB) update saw Uber discussing paying 1.9 shares for each GRUB share which would value the co. at USD 6bln or just over USD 60/shr, according to WSJ citing sources. However, the offer is slightly lower than what sources were suggesting yesterday (2 shares) and lower than what GRUB was said to be seeking. General Electric (GE) traded with heavy losses despite a lack of incremental news, although many are focusing on its struggling financial position in wake of the coronavirus. Intel (INTC) Capital has invested in two Chinese semiconductors start-ups, ProPlus, and Spectrum Materials. ProPlus makes EDA software that chipmakers use to design their products before manufacturing them and Spectrum Materials makes gases critical for semiconductor fabs to produce physical chips. Tesla (TSLA) can restart operations in Alameda County if guidance is followed. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) has dropped out of the USD 10bln casino project in Japan amid disagreements on licensing and tax terms. Mylan NV (MYL) announced a global collaboration with Gilead (GILD) to expand access to GILD’s experimental COVID treatment, remdesivir. MYL holds the rights to manufacture and distribute the treatment in 127 low-middle income countries. Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) is developing a new total COVID-19 antibodies test and will seek FDA emergency authorization and international approval for the test over the next few weeks; will begin manufacturing in the next few weeks. Uber (UBER) has rejected a 2.15 share ratio in GrubHub (GRUB) deal talks & the companies remain at odds on price, sources tell CNBC. Barclays believes GRUB could be worth USD 75/shr in a sale. Caterpillar (CAT) 3-mth machine retail sales (end-Apr.): NA -27%, APAC -17%, LATAM -28%, World -22%. Intelsat (I) may reportedly file for its Chapter 11 bankruptcy as soon as tonight, some reports suggested. SPX -1.75% at 2820, NDQ -1.2% at 9000, DJIA -2.17% at 23,245.

The Treasury curve bull-flattened amid a souring of risk appetite (SPX sell-off), with yields falling lower despite the record Treasury 30-year issuance and other supply. T-Notes went into the US session with a modest bid, to then see a spike higher upon the Fed Chair Powell speech text release, which at first gave no mention to negative rates and said the Fed would use its tools “fully”, thus traders took this as a cue for somewhat of an endorsement for negative rates, as seen in the Fed Funds futures curve. However, when Powell was pressed in his Q&A on the issue of NIRP, he made it clear that the Fed was not considering the policy, which saw a pushing-out of the NIRP pricing along the FF term structure. The bias on the day was for a flatter curve amid risk pressure, nonetheless, and the curve resumed its bull-flattening heading into the 30-year auction. The auction tailed the 1.334% WI by 0.8bps, although the internals weren’t bad given the Bond has been heavily bid in the past few session: covered 2.30x (vs avg. 2.40x), dealers took 21.38% (vs avg. 19.8%), indirects 65.69% (vs avg. 63.8%). Some desks draw attention to the recent cheapening of USD hedging costs, thus increasing the allure of USTs to international investors. Meanwhile, the deluge of corporate and Sovereign, Supranational and Agency issuance fails to remove the sails out of US duration bulls either, UnitedHealth came to the primary market with a USD 5bln offering. By settlement, the Treasury curve was flatter, with yields lower by a basis point or so at the front-end and down by over 4bps in the 30-year. US T-note futures (M0) settled 8+ ticks higher at 139-07.

subject: Japan's Government is reportedly looking to create a scheme that injects capital into large and medium sized firms suffering from COVID-19, according to Nikkei
Newsquawk US Market Wrap - May 13th: Stocks finish red as Powell pushes back on NIRP
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Powell pushes back on NIRP; US/China relations continue to sour; OPEC cuts global oil demand forecast. RBNZ expand QE, open door for negative rates, UK GDP better than expected, still grim.
  • COMING UP: Data: German CPI (Final), US Import/Export Prices, Initial Jobless Claims, New Zealand Manufacturing PMI. Speakers: Fed's Kashkari, ECB's de Guindos, BoJ's Kuroda, German Chancellor Merkel. Event: IEA Monthly Oil Market Report. Supply: UK & US. Earnings: Deutsche Telekom

MARKET WRAP

Equities endured another down day (ES printed sub 2,800 briefly), and the VIX jumped back higher rising into the 37s, moving out of contango; stock losses attributed to Fed chair Powell pushing back against the idea of negative US rates, and US/China tensions ramping up again ahead of November’s Presidential elections. This downside has not been unexpected; recall, Goldman Sachs on the weekend provided a list of reasons why equities could see downside this week, without a specific headline catalyst (US/China risks were an identified risk); while others have suggested that the bear market rally is now over; that caution has been heard from some very influential investors too. Today, Appaloosa’s Tepper made similar warnings to those of Stan Druckenmiller yesterday, while recent commentary from BlackRock’s Fink and Berkshire Hathaway’s Buffett all seem to be calling into question the potential for large equity upside. Meanwhile, bonds bull-flattened amid the negative risk tone (the long-end auction was lacklustre, tailing 0.8bps), the Dollar Index rose back above 100.00, gold made some progress above USD 1,700 after Powell. Retail sales and initial jobless claims are on the slate for Thursday.

NORTH AMERICA

US/CHINA: Tensions between US/China are clearly picking up; China's Foreign Ministry, on President Trump's efforts to push TSP fund to halt planned investments, said the wanton placement of obstructions on US investors runs counter to economic law; nevertheless, the US retirement investment board delayed the transition of USD 40bln international fund to track the MSCI index, including controversial Chinese equities, according to a statement, which cited COVID-19 and new board nominations as the reason behind the delay. Desks have been closely watching this aspect of the tensions; any restrictions on portfolio flows would be taken as a negative, and while this does not specifically call for the withdrawing of capital from Chinese equities, fund managers that track the index will be aware of the potential for disruptive flows. US President Trump, meanwhile, said dealing with China was "a very expensive thing to do," and "100 Trade Deals wouldn’t make up the difference" for the downside that has come as a result of President Trump calling the coronavirus the "China plague," a description likely to irritate the Chinese. However, there was also punchy rhetoric from China too; China's Global Times newspaper reported it would soon impose countermeasures on US individuals and entities filing lawsuits seeking COVID-19 damages from China, according to sources, and US states that were to sue China were highly likely to face business and trade consequences. Meanwhile, Huawei and ZTE were back in the frame, with US President Trump extending the executive order protecting the US supply chain from Huawei and ZTE for an additional year. The key takeaway is that US/China headline risk is firmly back now, and many desks are attributing developments as a key contribution (among other reasons) for why equities have seen downside over the last couple of days.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED CHAIR POWELL: While the initial text release was largely in line with recent commentary, in his Q&A, Fed Chair Powell pushed back against the idea of negative rates, which saw pricing of such a scenario push further out the Federal Funds Futures term structure. Powell again cited the mixed evidence on negative rates, though some traders noted that he used the caveat “for now” implying that the FOMC would likely want the option in its toolbox in the future. Some analysts have suggested that this line makes sense; the Fed would be able to exhaust other policy options first before resorting to more aggressive policies. The second stand out was that the Fed chair urged fiscal action; while this is not particularly new (he has said so many times recently), his remark that the Fed will be able to help companies with liquidity issues for a while, over time, more fiscal help will be needed; Powell also argued that now was not the time to debate debt and deficit levels (seemingly taking aim at some Republican lawmaker concerns). All in all, the message ultimately remains the same: The Fed is not going anywhere anytime soon, although fiscal authorities will need to step up eventually. Negative rates are not on the radar, but the market is retaining a non-zero chance of seeing them next year.

ECB: ECB's de Guindos expects the eurozone economy to rebound in Q3 and Q4, expects growth of 6% in 2021, although the level of uncertainty is still very high and says it will take the eurozone two years to fully recover. De Guindos adds, Eurozone Banks will overcome the current crisis, although their results will suffer, adding banks will have to further reduce excess capacity and eventually embark on national and cross-border mergers within the EZ. ECB's chief economist Lane says low rates help, not hurt, banks. On the GCC, ECB, Bundesbank and German Gov't are reportedly attempting to find a face-saving way to defuse to danger from the GCC ruling on the Euro-Area integrity; Bundesbank could write the report or the ECB could but it would not be official, according to die Zeit's Schieritz. Meanwhile, German Chancellor Merkel stated they will respect the constitutional court's ruling on the ECB and the German government will answer questions from the EU Commission. Merkel added she wants a strong Euro, so will proceed in that sense going forward. ECB's Rehn reiterated other officials that the GCC does not instantly affect ECB monetary policy, but it is essential that the GCC agrees with EU top court that the PSPP does not breach the ban on public sector Central Bank funding.

RBNZ: The RBNZ opted to keep its OCR at 0.25% and aggressively expanded its QE programme to NZD 60bln from NZD 33bln, as expected. Interestingly, the Board signalled openness towards a negative key rate, albeit the statement noted that now is not the time, so it reaffirmed its forward guidance that the “OCR would remain at 0.25% until early-2021”. Analysts at Westpac downplay the significance of the forward guidance and state that it will not stand in the way of NIRP if the situation requires it. That being said, at the presser, the RBNZ unveiled that it had asked banks to be on standby for negative rates by year-end. The Central Bank also noted that the purchase of foreign bonds is a possibility should more stimulus be required. Westpac forecasts the OCR to be reduced to -0.5% in November 2020 and remain comfortable with their NIRP forecast, but “timing is looking less certain”, the bank says.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 8+ TICKS HIGHER AT 139-07

The Treasury curve bull-flattened amid a souring of risk appetite (SPX sell-off), with yields falling lower despite the record Treasury 30-year issuance and other supply. T-Notes went into the US session with a modest bid, to then see a spike higher upon the Fed Chair Powell speech text release, which at first gave no mention to negative rates and said the Fed would use its tools “fully”, thus traders took this as a cue for somewhat of an endorsement for negative rates, as seen in the Fed Funds futures curve. However, when Powell was pressed in his Q&A on the issue of NIRP, he made it clear that the Fed was not considering the policy, which saw a pushing-out of the NIRP pricing along the FF term structure. The bias on the day was for a flatter curve amid risk pressure, nonetheless, and the curve resumed its bull-flattening heading into the 30-year auction. The auction tailed the 1.334% WI by 0.8bps, although the internals weren’t bad given the Bond has been heavily bid in the past few session: covered 2.30x (vs avg. 2.40x), dealers took 21.38% (vs avg. 19.8%), indirects 65.69% (vs avg. 63.8%). Some desks draw attention to the recent cheapening of USD hedging costs, thus increasing the allure of USTs to international investors. Meanwhile, the deluge of corporate and Sovereign, Supranational and Agency issuance fails to remove the sails out of US duration bulls either, UnitedHealth came to the primary market with a USD 5bln offering. By settlement, the Treasury curve was flatter, with yields lower by a basis point or so at the front-end and down by over 4bps in the 30-year

CRUDE

WTI (M0) SETTLES USD 0.49 LOWER AT USD 25.29; WTI (N0) SETTLES USD 0.65 LOWER AT USD 25.68; BRENT (N0) SETTLES USD 0.79 LOWER AT USD 29.19

Crude futures moved lower on Wednesday, taking their cues from wider risk aversion, despite the latest reassuring US inventory levels. Futures had been firmer overnight, catching some tailwinds after the private data suggested the Cushing hub had seen crude stocks draw for the first time in weeks – reducing concerns somewhat of storage reaching capacity ahead of June WTI expiry next Tuesday. The tone was reiterated in the official EIA data today, which even reported a surprise draw (albeit narrow) in total crude stocks, in addition to the 3mln bbls draw at Cushing; products were mixed, while crude production fell by 300k BPD to 11.6mln BPD. However, another acute sell-off in Spooz managed to weigh on the energy complex, bringing it into the red in the latter part of the session. Elsewhere, Politico reported that the White House has appealed the order to halt the Keystone XL pipeline construction. Iraq said it would bring total cuts to around 700k BPD, after agreeing with oil majors to cut production in Southern fields by 300k BPD. Saudi Arabia and Russia said they see signs of a recovery in oil demand and are confident OPEC+ partners are fully aligned with their goals.

OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 2.23mln BPD from the prior report (Prev. cut of 6.9mln BPD), now forecast at 9.07mln BPD. The report reiterated that the worst contraction is expected to take place in Q2. Click here for full report.

DATA

UK GDP: Q1 GDP metrics saw a decline of 2% Q/Q, which was slightly better than the anticipated decline of 2.5%, with the March-specific metric showing a contraction of 5.7% (exp. -8.0%); Some desks pointed out that the magnitude of the March decline was roughly the same amount of growth lost for the UK as seen during the peak-to-trough of the financial crisis. Pantheon Macroeconomics noted that the 2% contraction was not as severe as forecast by the MPC in its latest MPR, however, this could be a by-product of data collection quirks at the ONS where some data inputs were not available. Additionally, it is also worth considering the timing of the lockdown in the UK (23rd March) and therefore even the March-specific print will have only provided limited insight into the fragility of the UK economy. As such (and as is the case for most global economies), focus instead will likely fall more on the Q2 outturn, which Pantheon Macroeconomics suggests could see a Q/Q contraction of 20% even in the event that activity slowly begins to normalise towards the end of May. Framing a view of economic performance in Q2 will play a key role in assessing the shape of the eventual recovery in the UK with the prospect of a V-shaped recovery regarded to be in the rear-view mirror of many economists. Any further downside outcomes on this front will likely challenge the view of the BoE in its latest MPR that economic activity could return to pre-COVID-19 levels in H2 2021; some believe this is not likely until at least 2022.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -1.75% at 2820, NDQ -1.2% at 9000, DJIA -2.17% at 23,245

SECTORS: Energy -4.4%, Financials -3%, Communications -2.9%, Industrials -2.6%, Materials -2.2%, Technology -1.7%, Real Estate -1.6%, Discretionary -1.2%, Health Care -1.1%, Staples -0.9%, Utilities -0.9%

STOCK SPECIFICS: The latest Uber (UBER) and Grubhub (GRUB) update saw Uber discussing paying 1.9 shares for each GRUB share which would value the co. at USD 6bln or just over USD 60/shr, according to WSJ citing sources. However, the offer is slightly lower than what sources were suggesting yesterday (2 shares) and lower than what GRUB was said to be seeking. General Electric (GE) traded with heavy losses despite a lack of incremental news, although many are focusing on its struggling financial position in wake of the coronavirus. Intel (INTC) Capital has invested in two Chinese semiconductors start-ups, ProPlus, and Spectrum Materials. ProPlus makes EDA software that chipmakers use to design their products before manufacturing them and Spectrum Materials makes gases critical for semiconductor fabs to produce physical chips. Tesla (TSLA) can restart operations in Alameda County if guidance is followed. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) has dropped out of the USD 10bln casino project in Japan amid disagreements on licensing and tax terms. Mylan NV (MYL) announced a global collaboration with Gilead (GILD) to expand access to GILD’s experimental COVID treatment, remdesivir. MYL holds the rights to manufacture and distribute the treatment in 127 low-middle income countries. Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) is developing a new total COVID-19 antibodies test and will seek FDA emergency authorization and international approval for the test over the next few weeks; will begin manufacturing in the next few weeks. Uber (UBER) has rejected a 2.15 share ratio in GrubHub (GRUB) deal talks & the companies remain at odds on price, sources tell CNBC. Barclays believes GRUB could be worth USD 75/shr in a sale. Caterpillar (CAT) 3-mth machine retail sales (end-Apr.): NA -27%, APAC -17%, LATAM -28%, World -22%. Intelsat (I) may reportedly file for its Chapter 11 bankruptcy as soon as tonight, some reports suggested.

FX WRAP

USD: The DXY swung each side of the 100 figure with weakness heading into Fed Chair Powell’s speech, although as Powell pushed back on negative rates (which set the tone for the rest of the day) saw the dollar claw back gains and cross the 100 level to the upside, entering positive territory. Amid the Powell push back, ties between the US and China continue to fade amid reports of the US retirement investment board delaying the transition of USD 40bln international fund to track the MSCI index, which includes controversial Chinese companies, while further action has been taken against Huawei and ZTE, with the Chinese considering countermeasures on US individuals who file lawsuits seeking COVID-19 damages from China, all building a rather gloomy backdrop.

HAVENS (JPY, XAU): With china/US relationships souring from multiple angles both JPY and XAU were bid, although price action was limited. Gains were likely also capped as Powell pushed back on negative rates, a tool which is normally supportive for both JPY and XAU due to rate differentials and real yields. Meanwhile, cyclical FX was weaker in the US session as risk sentiment continued to deteriorate amid growing US/China relationship concerns and Fed Chair Powell leaning on risk.

NZD: The G10 underperformer after a dovish RBNZ rate decision which left its cash rate unchanged at 0.25%, while expanding its QE programme to NZD 60bln from NZD 33bln, while leaving the door open to negative interest rates; it however maintained forward guidance that the cash rate is to be at 0.25% until early 2021, while reiterating negative rates cannot be used currently due to operational issues at banks. Westpac notes that forward guidance is regularly updated, and thus feel comfortable keeping its own forecast that the OCR will fall to -0.5% in November.

GBP, AUD: Sterling and the Aussie both saw similar losses against the rising buck today. GBP saw its GDP release this morning which fared ‘better’ than expected, as was IP, although overall still a grim report but support was provided to GBP. However, as risk sentiment soured and the dollar climbed, Sterling was pressured. Meanwhile, BoE Governor Bailey when asked about austerity policies said he hopes fiscal authorities will consider all choices, adding the BoE can help spread the cost out of COVID overtime. Bailey also reiterated a willingness to increase government bond purchases. AUD tracked risk appetite while looming Aussie/China concerns also contributing to the downside, though a big rise in Westpac’s consumer confidence index may have limited the downside.

COMMODITY FX (MXN, CAD): The crude complex saw downside today which weighed on petro-currencies, with EMs in general under the cosh. MXN, however, was the outlier and appreciated against the buck as its economy looks set to reopen while it has allowed automakers to resume production on May 18th. CAD was marginally weaker in fitting with risk appetite and crude prices. Scotiabank wrote if the risk backdrop were to improve could see USDCAD test 1.38/1.39, although if there were a sharp fall in equities, 1.41/1.42 could be seen. The desk, however, continues to expect CAD will remain around the 1.40 figure.

EMFX: EMFX was mixed, TRY continued its rebound and MXN benefitted from reopening news. Elsewhere BRL saw continued weakness and edged closer towards the 6.00 handle while Bolsonaro faces accusations from the former Justice Minister which, according to an Attorney General, if true, he would have been breaking multiple laws. The soured risk appetite today is also largely to blame for the EMFX hit.

TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note futures (M0) settled 8+ ticks higher at 139-07
analysis_details: The Treasury curve bull-flattened amid a souring of risk appetite (SPX sell-off), with yields falling lower despite the record Treasury 30-year issuance and other supply. T-Notes went into the US session with a modest bid, to then see a spike higher upon the Fed Chair Powell speech text release, which at first gave no mention to negative rates and said the Fed would use its tools “fully”, thus traders took this as a cue for somewhat of an endorsement for negative rates, as seen in the Fed Funds futures curve. However, when Powell was pressed in his Q&A on the issue of NIRP, he made it clear that the Fed was not considering the policy, which saw a pushing-out of the NIRP pricing along the FF term structure. The bias on the day was for a flatter curve amid risk pressure, nonetheless, and the curve resumed its bull-flattening heading into the 30-year auction. The auction tailed the 1.334% WI by 0.8bps, although the internals weren’t bad given the Bond has been heavily bid in the past few session: covered 2.30x (vs avg. 2.40x), dealers took 21.38% (vs avg. 19.8%), indirects 65.69% (vs avg. 63.8%). Some desks draw attention to the recent cheapening of USD hedging costs, thus increasing the allure of USTs to international investors. Meanwhile, the deluge of corporate and Sovereign, Supranational and Agency issuance fails to remove the sails out of US duration bulls either, UnitedHealth came to the primary market with a USD 5bln offering. By settlement, the Treasury curve was flatter, with yields lower by a basis point or so at the front-end and down by over 4bps in the 30-year.

subject: CRUDE WRAP: WTI (M0) settles USD 0.49 lower at USD 25.29; WTI (N0) settles USD 0.65 lower at USD 25.68; Brent (N0) settles USD 0.79 lower at USD 29.19
analysis_details:
Crude futures moved lower on Wednesday, taking their cues from wider risk aversion, despite the latest reassuring US inventory levels. Futures had been firmer overnight, catching some tailwinds after the private data suggested the Cushing hub had seen crude stocks draw for the first time in weeks – reducing concerns somewhat of storage reaching capacity ahead of June WTI expiry next Tuesday. The tone was reiterated in the official EIA data today, which even reported a surprise draw (albeit narrow) in total crude stocks, in addition to the 3mln bbls draw at Cushing; products were mixed, while crude production fell by 300k BPD to 11.6mln BPD. However, another acute sell-off in Spooz managed to weigh on the energy complex, bringing it into the red in the latter part of the session. Elsewhere, Politico reported that the White House has appealed the order to halt the Keystone XL pipeline construction. Iraq said it would bring total cuts to around 700k BPD, after agreeing with oil majors to cut production in Southern fields by 300k BPD. Saudi Arabia and Russia said they see signs of a recovery in oil demand and are confident OPEC+ partners are fully aligned with their goals.

OPEC MONTHLY REPORT: 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 2.23mln BPD from prior report (Prev. cut of 6.9mln BPD), now forecast at 9.07mln BPD. Report reiterated that the worst contraction is expected to take place in Q2. Click here for full report.

subject: Appaloosa’s David Tepper says the market is one of the most overvalued markets he has seen, behind only 1999
content: • Notes there is not good risk/reward here
analysis_details: • Tepper is echoing comments from influential investor Stan Druckenmiller, who delivered sobering comments to the Economic Club of NY aftermarket on Tuesday, suggesting that the risk-reward for equities was as bad as he's ever seen it in his career, and stocks were historically overvalued. He also argued that markets were overreacting to the progress of anti COVID treatments. Druckenmiller also does not buy into the theory that the Fed has the market's back (i.e. has backstopped the downside), and argued that what we were seeing is not capitalism. He also warned of bankruptcies ahead, in addition to more regulation and higher taxes ahead due to COVID.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar gets a fillip from Fed chair Powell, eventually
content:
USD

No mention of NIRP in the prepared text, but the concept was dealt with and denounced if not completely dismissed by the Fed chair during the Q&A, as Powell stated no change in the very mixed evaluation of the efficacy of sub-zero rates and referred to prior FOMC minutes revealing that ‘all’ participants are opposed to negative Fed Funds. Hence, the DXY seems to have found a floor above 99.500 amidst broad Greenback recovery gains and the index is probing back above the 100.000 level that has been pivotal in May.

NZD/AUD 

A real whip-saw Wednesday for the Kiwi, but perhaps crucially no loss of the 0.6000 handle vs the Buck even though the RBNZ has rekindled NIRP expectations via latest policy guidance that accompanied boosting QE and expanding the basket of purchases overnight. Perhaps decent option expiry interest at the strike kept Nzd/Usd underpinned, though the pair has retreated sharply from earlier recovery peaks and Aud/Nzd remains elevated within a wide 1.0780-1.0620 or so range even though the Aussie has relinquished 0.6500+ status against its US counterpart ahead of April’s labour report.

NOK/SEK

The standout G10 winner, with Eur/Nok finally breaching 11.0000 on a combination of bearish technical momentum and independent support for the Norwegian Krona via Norges Bank Governor Olsen reaffirming that this month’s 25 bp ease to 0% will likely be the final cut. However, the Swedish Crown’s post-Riksbank bull run has been hampered somewhat above 10.6000 vs the Euro in wake of deflationary CPI and CPIF readings that could convince the Bank to relent on its reluctance towards reversing its decision to lift the benchmark repo rate back to parity.

CAD/EUR/JPY/CHF/GBP

Relative stability in oil after an unexpected draw in EIA crude stocks and more cohesive commentary from Russia and Saudi Arabia along the lines of expediting market rebalancing, not to mention both seeing signs of demand recovering, has protected the Loonie from losing too much ground vs its US rival. Indeed, Usd/Cad has been pretty confined between 1.4005-85 parameters and orbiting 1.4050 for the most part, like Eur/Usd around 1.0850 after inching closer to 1.0900 pre-Powell, Usd/Jpy either side of 107.00 and Usd/Chf in relation to 0.9700. Conversely, Sterling has underperformed across the board following fleeting reprieves on not quite as dire UK data as forecast and the aforementioned pre-Fed chair Dollar weakness, with Cable tripping stops circa 1.2250 and now through support ahead of 1.2200, while Eur/Gbp has rebounded from around 0.8809 to almost 0.8800.

EM 

Risk-off sentiment is weighing on most regional currencies, but the Try is holding above 7.0000 and Mxn welcoming plans to re-open the economy ahead of an expected ½ point Banxico rate cut tomorrow. However, the Brl remains beset with political issues and the economic fallout from COVID-19 that prompted the Government to slash its 2020 GDP and inflation estimates rather than getting any lasting relief from retail sales falling less than anticipated in March.

subject: Brazil Gov't lowers their 2020 GDP growth forecast to -4.7% (Prev. 0.0%), according to the Economy Ministry; cuts inflation forecast to 1.8% (Prev. 3.1%)
Fed Chair Powell is to testify to the Senate Banking Committee on May 19th alongside US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin
US EQUITY OPEN NOTE: Equities open in the red continuing declines as Powell pushes back on NIRP
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: US equities have come under pressure after Fed Chair Powell strongly leaned back against the idea of negative rates; that seems to be setting the tone for today’s session; the buck is paring back, and currencies that saw gains on the weakness are pressured, with the exception of the kiwi, which remains strongly lower as the RBNZ boosts QE and hints at going negative. The Treasury curve is bull flattening (slightly), and bond traders are eyeing the 30-year auction this afternoon. Gold continues to consolidate around USD 1,700. NIH Director Fauci’s cautious comments cap optimism, while traders are cognizant of US/China risks, with talk on Capitol Hill of possible sanctions measures against the Chinese. Powell’s urging of fiscal action is also likely to keep attention on stimulus headlines.

SECTORS: All sectors open in negative territory after steep declines yesterday. Defensives the relative outperformers (along with Technology) while Energy and Financials are leading the losses with the former weighed on by Exxon Mobil (XOM) after the ISS recommended shareholders vote against the separation of its CEO and Chairman roles. Financials likely weighed on from lower yields amid comments from Fed Chair Powell who noted the Fed will continue to use its tools to the fullest, while in the Q&A he was noted the view of the committee has not changed in NIRP and it is not something being considered “for now”, suggesting it has not been completely ruled out which may be weighing on banks.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Intel (INTC) Capital has invested in two Chinese semiconductors start-ups, ProPlus, and Spectrum Materials. ProPlus makes EDA software that chipmakers use to design their products before manufacturing them and Spectrum Materials makes gases critical for semiconductor fabs to produce physical chips. Tesla (TSLA) can restart operations in Alameda County if guidance is followed. Las Vegas Sands (LVS) has dropped out of the USD 10bln casino project in Japan amid disagreements on licensing and tax terms. Mylan NV (MYL) announced a global collaboration with Gilead (GILD) to expand access to GILD’s experimental COVID treatment, remdesivir. MYL holds the rights to manufacture and distribute the treatment in 127 low-middle income countries. Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) is developing a new total COVID-19 antibodies test and will seek FDA emergency authorization and international approval for the test over the next few weeks; will begin manufacturing in the next few weeks. Uber (UBER) has rejected a 2.15 share ratio in GrubHub (GRUB) deal talks & the companies remain at odds on price, sources tell CNBC. Barclays believes GRUB could be worth USD 75/shr in a sale. Caterpillar (CAT) 3-mth machine retail sales (end-Apr.): NA -27%, APAC -17%, LATAM -28%, World -22%.

POWELL: While the text was largely in line with recent commentary, in the Q&A, Fed chair Powell pushed back against the idea of negative rates, which saw pricing of such a scenario push further out the Federal Funds Futures term structure. Powell again cited the mixed evidence on negative rates, though some traders noted that he used the caveat “for now” implying that the FOMC would likely want the option in its toolbox in the future. Some analysts have suggested that this line makes sense; the Fed would be able to exhaust other policy options first before resorting to more aggressive policies. The second stand out was that the Fed chair urged fiscal action; while this is not particularly new (he has said so many times recently), his remark that the Fed will be able to help companies with liquidity issues for a while, over time, more fiscal help will be needed; Powell also argued that now was not the time to debate debt and deficit levels (seemingly taking aim at some Republican lawmaker concerns). All in all, the message ultimately remains the same: The Fed is not going anywhere anytime soon, although fiscal authorities will need to step up eventually. Negative rates are not on the radar, but the market is retaining a non-zero chance of seeing them next year.

ABOUT LAST NIGHT: The SPX fell in afternoon trade on Tuesday, backed by very little news flow. At the time, Treasuries were stable, as was oil in post-settlement trade, which has led some to suggest that the downside was a result of a chunky sell-side imbalance in thin market conditions; others suggested it was a result of cautious comments from NIH director Fauci, although the timing of the comments and market moves do not coincide. Nevertheless, the downside was not surprising to some, including analysts at Goldman Sachs; earlier in the week, we wrote about why this rally is unloved, and provided Goldman’s six reasons why the market could be in store for downside; 1) COVID infection rates outside of NY continue to rise, and may accelerate as lockdowns are lifted; 2) the restart process will take time; 3) bank loan loss reserves were built in Q1 based on a jobless rate of around 10% - that rate rose to 14.7% in April, and GS forecasts loan loss provisions will need to rise to USD 115bln in the next four quarters (versus total of USD 46bln in Q1); this may weigh on share repurchase/buybacks plans, shaking a key pillar of support that equities have enjoyed in the last decade; 4) dividends are at risk, and are seen falling further this year, as too are capex plans; 5) tax policy risk around elections; tax reforms in 2017 lowered corporation tax to 18% from 26%, and may become a political issue; 6) US/China risks, a headwind in 2019, are resurfacing.

END OF BEAR MARKET RALLY: Nomura's quants think the bear market rally in equities has run its course, and we will now see a temporary market cool-down, as catalysts for a swing to genuine bullishness seem to be lacking, and stock market sentiment in the US is tracking its median recovery trajectory that it has historically seen after steep falls. Another reason Nomura offers is due to the way CTAs have started selling equity futures globally; its model shows CTAs cutting longs in S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures, and for the latter, the trigger line appears to be around 8,450, Nomura says. The model also suggests CTAs have growing shorts in Russell 2000 and Dow Jones futures. The bank suggests that there has been little FOMO from global macro hedge funds too in the latest rally, with these funds seeing opportunities for short-covering. "We therefore think that chain-reaction selling of the sort that would pull DM equity markets down sharply looks unlikely," it caveats.

DRUCKENMILLER: Influential investor Stan Druckenmiller delivered sobering comments to the Economic Club of NY aftermarket on Tuesday, suggesting that the risk-reward for equities was as bad as he's ever seen it in his career, and stocks were historically overvalued. He also argued that markets were overreacting to the progress of anti COVID treatments. Druckenmiller also does not buy into the theory that the Fed has the market's back (i.e. has backstopped the downside), and argued that what we were seeing is not capitalism. He also warned of bankruptcies ahead, in addition to more regulation and higher taxes ahead due to COVID.

SNAP ANALYSIS: Powell sticks to script (no mention of negative rates in the text), says Fed will use tools to the “fullest”, and again urges fiscal action
content:
• These seem to be a neutral set of comments from Powell; while there is no explicit mention of negative rates, the Fed chair says the central bank will use its tools to the fullest, which may imply some optionality to use the measure in the future if the situation requires.
  • Powell again says additional fiscal support could be costly, but would be worth it if it helped to avoid long-term economic damage; his remarks are particularly interesting in the context that Democratic lawmakers in the House introduced a stimulus package on Tuesday which has been pushed back on by Republicans.
  • From the comments, there is no reason to assume that the Fed will not carry on doing exactly what it has been doing, will not pull support any time soon, and will act further if needed.
  • The market reaction has leaned slightly dovish and negative rate expectations have ramped-up in terms of scale and timing with Jan21 now at 100.000 and the curve inverting from there.

FFF pricing vs Fed’s Powell in the context of NIRP
content: The Fed Fund Futures strip was relatively dovish going in given parity implied from the Feb21 contract compared to April or March next year at the earliest on Tuesday, but following the FOMC chair’s comments at the Peterson Institute negative rate expectations have ramped up in terms of scale and timing with Jan21 now at 100.000 and the curve inverting from there. To recap, no actual mention of NIRP in the text, but no explicit rejection seems to have been construed that sub-zero may well be within the Fed’s full policy range.

content:
• Will use tools to their "fullest" until the crisis has passed and recovery is well underway

reaction_details:

Additionally, the Fed Chair painted a relatively grim picture for the US economy.

subject: OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report (May): 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down, reiterates worst contraction expected to take place in Q2
content:
MAIN POINTS

  • 2020 global oil demand growth forecast revised down by 2.23mln BPD from prior report (Prev. cut of 6.9mln BPD), now forecast at 9.07mln BPD.
  • Report reiterates the worst contraction expected to take place in Q2

CORONAVIRUS

  • The world economy GDP revised down to -3.5% (Prev. -1.5%); a recovery is forecast as soon as lockdown measures are lifted
  • A considerable positive impact from lockdown easing is expected in H2 2020

STORAGE

  • Concerns were raised that global storage capacity could reach its maximum limit within weeks into Q2 2020
  • The expected voluntary and involuntary production reductions are expected to weigh on tanker demand in the coming months, although increased floating storage will provide offsetting support.

OPEC-13

  • In April, OPEC crude production rose by 1.8mln BPD MM to average 30.41mln BPD, according to secondary sources. Crude output increased in mainly in Saudi Arabia, UAE and Kuwait, whilst production fell mostly in Angola, Nigeria, Iran and Iraq.
  • Following the OPEC+ meeting, demand for OPEC crude is expected at 24.3mln BPD, -5.6mln BPD YY
  • However, recently announced over-compliance by Saudi, UAE and Kuwait are likely to improve demand for OPEC crude in 2020

NON-OPEC

  • 2020 Former Soviet Union oil supply forecast unchanged at 1.65mln BPD following last month’s significant revision lower.

US

  • US crude oil production in 2020 is forecast revised down by 1.13mln BPD YY to average 11.10mln BPD (Prev. 12.03mln BPD)
  • Preliminary data indicates that US crude oil imports in April fell to 5.4mln BPD (vs. Prev. 6.3mln BPD)
  • US crude exports in April averaged 3.2mln BPD, down from February peak of 3.7mln BPD

OECD

  • OECD oil demand was revised down by 1.2mln BPD from the prior report.
analysis_details:
• The global oil demand cut by OPEC chimes with that of the EIA STEO, who reduced their forecasts by 2.9mln BPD to decline 8.13mln BPD.
  • US oil output forecasts from both the EIA and OPEC were revised lower to 11.69mln BPD and 11.1mln BPD respectively
  • The release itself is backwards looking and likely stale given the fluidity surround reopening economies alongside future implications of the unfolding US-China trade tensions.
  • The June release will be eyed to get a cleaner picture as to whether OPEC++ complied with the agreed upon curbs

subject: WATCH LIVE: Fed Chair Powell to speak on the economy at 0900 ET/1400 BST
content:
WATCH LIVE: The event can be streamed online via the Peterson Institute.

Powell’s remarks are likely to be a reiteration of his post-FOMC comments on 29th April. However, there are a few key themes we will be paying close attention to:

NEGATIVE RATES: Last week, some Federal Funds Futures contracts rose above par, signalling a modest but non-zero probability that the US will see negative rates. Fed officials including Powell have largely pushed back against this notion both recently and historically, stating it would not be an appropriate policy in the US. However, some officials (like dovish voter Kashkari), while not favouring the policy, have not completely ruled it out in the future. And then there is the political pressure from US President Trump, who has previously given mixed signals, this week called negative rates a “gift”. While Powell will likely argue against the policy again, analysts will be watching how aggressively he does so; leaving any optionality to use the policy in the future will likely keep those Fed Funds futures next year pricing some probability of negative rates, albeit moderate for now. In terms of market reaction, negative rates, while assumed to be dollar negative, might not be as negative as first perceived, Credit Suisse says; the bank notes USD-negative repercussions may be limited by the fact that most other major central banks will also be toying with negative rates and QE policies. For equities, when those FF futures began rising above par, it stoked equity upside. 

YCC: Analysts believe that the Fed will eventually announce a yield curve control policy to put a lid on shorter-dated yields, and it could be used in combination with a pledge to keep rates low for a long, long time. This would keep rates low for both businesses and consumers during the recovery phase, but also provide favourable conditions for the US government to borrow at low levels to finance relief measures. Many think that the Fed would likely exhaust policies like YCC before resorting to negative rates. While the expectation is that such a policy might be announced at the June FOMC, some suggest it will still be a while before the Fed is ready to implement it. Accordingly, any commentary about timelines will be of use. BMO's analysts have suggested that a YCC policy would help the curve steepen out (short-end yields anchored by the Fed guidance and yield control, while longer-dated yields would rise on large Treasury issuance and the theoretical inflation and growth that recent stimulus fosters).

STIMULUS: The Fed chair is likely to reiterate that both fiscal and monetary authorities will need to do more to ensure that the recovery is robust. His remarks will be interesting given that Democrats in the House unveiled Stimulus v4.0, which Republicans have pushed back against, preferring to see how current measures play out before launching further largesse.

A recap of the April FOMC meeting and press conference can be found here and here.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th May 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses remain in proximity to negative opening levels while US futures are modestly firmer ahead of Fed Chair Powell before the open
  • US Republican Senators proposed legislation which would empower President Trump to impose sanctions on China if it does not provide a "full accounting" for the coronavirus outbreak.
  • Ahead of Powell (preview on Newsquawk feed), Fed’s Mester (Voter) said she would like to stay away from negative rates because it would impact money markets and suggested that negative rates won’t work in the US economy
  • RBNZ kept the OCR unchanged at 0.25% and boosted the Large Scale Asset Purchases programme to NZD 60bln; added, negative OCR becomes an option in the future
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, DoEs, OPEC monthly oil report, ECB's Lane, de Guindos, Fed's Powell, supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

University of Washington's coronavirus mortality model now projects 147k deaths in US by August which is 10k higher than previous forecast. (Newswires)

House Democrats Progressive Caucus asked House Speaker Pelosi to delay planned Friday vote on a new stimulus bill to next week. Furthermore, US Senate Majority Leader McConnell stated that he will insist on a narrow coronavirus response bill if there is to be one (CNN/Newswires)

US officials say Chinese and Iranian hackers could be hampering developments towards a vaccine, WSJ reports; Some have suggested there could be the prospect that such efforts are tantamount to an act of war. (WSJ)

Tokyo has 10 new cases of COVID-19, according to TBS

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly negative following the late slump on Wall St. and with sentiment soured by fears of a 2nd coronavirus wave, as well as efforts in the US Senate to impose sanctions on China. ASX 200 +0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were lower as the Australian benchmark suffered from the withered ties with China and amid initial losses in financials after the largest bank CBA reported a drop in cash profit and spike in loan impairment expenses, while sentiment in Tokyo was pressured by a firmer currency and with a slew of earnings releases dominating newsflow. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were both lacklustre as US-China concerns were stoked by reports of several measures in the US Senate against China including proposed legislation by Republican Senators that would empower President Trump to impose sanctions on China if it does not provide a "full accounting" for the coronavirus outbreak and with the Senate is also planning to move on legislation that would impose sanctions on Chinese officials over human rights abuses against Uighur Muslims. India markets bucked the trend with the Sensex (+2.0%) and Nifty (+2.0%) both surging at the open after PM Modi’s recent announcement of a special economic support package totalling INR 20tln, but with some of the gains pared amid the broad cautious tone in the region. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with the gains in T-notes, weakness in stocks and the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 810bln of JGBs all failing to spur prices.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the day. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0875 vs. Exp. 7.0867 (Prev. 7.0919) US Republican Senators proposed legislation which would empower President Trump to impose sanctions on China if it does not provide a "full accounting" for the coronavirus outbreak. In related news, the US Senate is planning to move on legislation that would impose sanctions on Chinese officials over human rights abuses against Uighur Muslims, while US Senator Cruz introduced legislation to incentivize mining companies to produce in the US and electronic manufacturers to use US based rare earths over China imports. (Newswires/The Hill/AFP)

Chinese Gov't advisor reportedly stated that the two sessions, referring to the NPC meeting, will not have much direct bearing for the trade deal; however, the language used will show how Beijing is to approach future deals with Washington. (SCMP)

China's Foreign Ministry, on President Trump's efforts to push TSP fund to halt planned investments, says Wanton placement of obstructions on US investors runs counter to economic law. (Newswires) 

BoJ cut Japanese ETF purchases today to JPY 100bln (Prev. 120bln). (Newswires)

US

Fed's Mester (voter, hawk) said this is the worst and speediest deterioration in the labor market many of us have ever seen and that Q2 will show most severe impact on the economy but added the baseline outlook is for economy to begin growing again in H2. Mester also said she would like to stay away from negative rates because it would impact money markets and suggested that negative rates won’t work in the US economy due to effects on banking system and mutual funds, while she noted that no tool is off the table but her preference is to use forward guidance and other measures first. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (non-voter, hawk) said he thinks we are at the bottom and headed up, while he reckons a clear plan to manage risks around the pandemic will inspire confidence to begin a recovery. (WSJ)

UK/EU

UK GDP Estimate MM (Mar) -5.8% vs. Exp. -8.0% (Prev. -0.1%)

UK GDP Preliminary QQ (Q1) -2.0% vs. Exp. -2.5%

UK GDP Estimate YY (Mar) -5.7% vs. Exp. -7.2% (Prev. 0.3%)

UK is reportedly on course for a budget deficit of GBP 337bln this year compared to the GBP 55bln forecast in March’s budget, according to reports citing a government document. As such, reports note that the Treasury could have to set out a proposed “policy package” of spending reductions and tax increases within weeks. (Telegraph) However, Chancellor Sunak later remarked that it would be premature to think about how the cost of COVID-19 can be repaid. (Newswires)

COVID-19 has "removed any prospect" of a full UK and US trade deal being finalised this year, according to a Harvard Kennedy School paper. The report notes that a "mini" deal could be reached but it would be of limited economic benefit to the UK and carry political costs. (Times) 

Barclaycard said UK consumer spending fell 36.5% Y/Y in April which was the largest decline since the survey began in 2015, while UK supermarket spending rose 14.3% Y/Y in April. (Newswires)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Apr) Y/Y 5.7% (Prev. -3.5%) excludes temporarily closed stores but includes online sales. (Newswires)

European Commission has proposed prolonging travel restrictions for people entering EU or Schengen State from outside to June 15th; setting out guidelines to allow safe resumption of tourism activities. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte's Cabinet is poised to approve Italy's EUR 55bln package. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities see losses across the region [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.3%] after a mixed APAC trade failed to induce upside in Europe. That being said, US equity futures eke mild gains early doors. Sentiment is weighed on over signs of a resurgence in COVID-19 cases across some economies opening “too early” – which could potentially prolong the reopening of those that are planning to in the immediate future. Further, worries over how the US-China trade situations will pan out also provides uncertainty to investors. Broad-based losses are seen across Europe, Switzerland’s SMI (-0.8%) fares slightly better as inflows into defensive stocks cushion the Pharma-heavy index. Sectors all reside in the red with defensives performing better than cyclicals – reflecting risk aversion; Consumer Discretionary names underperform. The sector breakdown provides little colour. In terms of individual movers; Anglo American (-1.9%), Glencore (-3.5%) and RWE (-2.6%) are weighed on by reports Norway’s sovereign wealth fund has sold its stakes in the Cos amid a breach of guidelines regarding the use of coal. The fund owned 2.4% of Anglo American, 1.2% of Glencore and 0.6% of RWE. Meanwhile, BHP (+0.2%), Enel (-2%) and Uniper (-0.7%) have been put on watch for a potential similar breach. The pre-market saw earnings from ABN AMRO (-7.2%) and Commerzbank (-6.6%), in which both banks reported deeper net losses and higher impairment charges than forecast. A.P. Moller Maersk (-5.9%) holds onto post-earning losses despite topping revenue and EBITDA estimates, as the Co. noted that Q2 volumes across all businesses could fall 20-25%, affecting both profitability and cash flow. Finally, no reprieve for Wirecard (-6%) after law firm TILP filed a lawsuit stating that Wirecard is liable to pay damages to shareholders amid a series of incorrect, omitted and incomplete capital market information.

Tencent (700 HK) - Q1 revenue CNY 108.065bln vs. Exp. CNY 101bln. Net CNY 28.896bln vs. Prev. CNY 27.210bln. Operating prof CNY 37.3bln vs. Exp. CNY 30.6bln. Combined WEIXIN and WECHAT MAUs 1.202bln vs. Prev. 1.1117bln

FX

NZD/AUD - A relatively large 815 mn option expiry at the 0.6000 strike may keep the Kiwi afloat, but the NIRP factor has really rattled the Nzd again after the RBNZ kept the door wide open to the possibility that the OCR could be lowered from the current 0.25% to sub-zero. To recap, QE was increased to Nzd 60 bn from Nzd 33 bn, as widely expected, and linkers will now be included in the asset purchase remit, but rate guidance was considerably more dovish than many envisaged to leave Nzd/Usd hovering just above the round number and Aud/Nzd not far from 1.0800 compared to around 1.0620 at one stage before the policy meeting. Conversely, the Aussie has gleaned some traction from an encouraging rebound in Westpac consumer sentiment that posted a record monthly rise in percentage terms on the eve of jobs data, with Aud/Usd nudging back up towards 0.6500 where 1 bn expiries roll off at today’s NY cut.

GBP/SEK/NOK - The Pound has recovered from another bout of seasonal May selling pressure, partly on technical grounds as Cable narrowly survived a test of key support at 1.2248, but also due to UK GDP and output for March/Q1 confounding consensus for significant declines, albeit still extremely weak. However, Sterling remains on the back foot below 1.2300 vs the Dollar and well under 0.8800 against a more rangy, resilient Euro in similar vein to the Swedish Crown that has retreated through 10.6000 in wake of headline and core inflation turning negative and sending another signal to the Riksbank that it may yet have to follow its Scandinavian neighbour with a conventional policy response. On that note, Eur/Nok has reversed more post-Norges Bank knee-jerk gains through 11.0000, but unconvincingly so far as Governor Olsen reiterates that the benchmark depo rate is unlikely to fall further from 0%.

CAD/EUR/CHF/JPY - Renewed risk aversion and a downturn in crude prices have not undermined the Loonie, though Usd/Cad is pivoting 1.4050 after touching 1.3900, as the DXY pares Tuesday’s relatively heavy retracement losses between 100.090-99.894 parameters awaiting Fed chair Powell’s address for the definitive word on negative rates and any other policy insight. Note also, hefty 1.5 bn expiry interest at the 1.4000 strike may keep the pair elevated ahead of Powell if not the NY cut. Meanwhile, the single currency and Swiss Franc have also lost momentum amidst the broad Buck revival, with Eur/Usd unable to challenge yesterday’s best and straddling 1.0850, Usd/Chf over 0.9700 again and Eur/Chf slightly firmer within a 1.0517-28 band, in contrast to the Yen that has rediscovered its safe-haven allure and eyeing 107.00 resistance and offers.

EM - Perhaps the most poignant test so far of the Lira’s new found power to resist bearish impulses as Usd/Try remains below the psychological 7.0000 level even though Turkey’s current account shortfall surpassed forecasts and almost quintupled in March from the previous month to a near 2 year wide deficit.

RBNZ kept the OCR unchanged at 0.25% and boosted the Large Scale Asset Purchases programme to NZD 60bln from NZD 33bln as expected, while it stated the LSAP programme will now include NZ government inflation indexed bonds and it expects retail interest rates to decline further. The Committee reaffirmed forward guidance that the OCR will remain at 0.25% until early 2021 but noted negative OCR will become an option in the future and that discussions with financial institutions regarding a negative OCR are ongoing. Furthermore, the central bank stated that financial institutions are not operationally ready for negative rates but they have asked banks to be ready by end of the year for negative rates and they agreed that a least regrets monetary policy approach is needed, delivering stimulus sooner rather than later. (Newswires)

FIXED

It’s been a slow grind from mixed starting points, but the midweek session is panning out much more positively for bonds across the board. Indeed, even BTPs and Bonos are back on the front foot after some initial qualms about ongoing German-ECB conflictions about asset buying, with the former also unwinding auction-related underperformance. Meanwhile, and not necessarily in tandem with deepest declines in equities, Bunds extended gains to 173.92 and Gilts to 138.00 before topping out at new, albeit marginal highs for the week. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain firm and the curve flatter into the last leg of this week’s bumper refunding and Fed chair Powell, with PPI somewhat overshadowed by CPI.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front month-futures extended on losses from the APAC session as sentiment across the market remains on the backfoot. Prices waned off OPEC sources highs potentially on worries surrounding US-Sino relations, but participants note that concerns over hitting storage capacity have eased as demand gradually recovers, whilst supply cuts also provides a less bearish outlook vs. March. Yesterday’s API printed a larger-than-expected build of 7.6mln barrels vs. Exp. 4.1mln, but Cushing saw a draw of 2.216mln barrels – traders will be eyeing today's DoEs for confirmation. Looking at the WTI forward curve, a chunk of open interest resides in the December 20 contract – reflecting funds’ moves from front-month to further down the line. Elsewhere, EIA STEO cut 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 2.9mln BPD to a decline of 8.13mln BPD Y/Y and its 2021 world oil demand forecast was cut by 580k BPD to 6.99mln BPD Y/Y increase, while it sees inventories to begin drawing in July 2020 and with draws continuing through the end  of 2021. The OPEC MOMR will be released later today. WTI June and Brent July both meander off session lows of USD 25.10/bbl (vs. high USD 25.81/bbl) and USD 28.92/bbl (vs. high USD 29.69/bbl) respectively. Meanwhile, spot gold remains lacklustre in a tight USD 6/oz range on either side of 1700/oz, awaiting Fed Chair Powel’s speech on current economic issues at 1400BST. Copper prices meanwhile initially extended on losses amid concerns on the US-China trade front coupled by resurfacings COVID-19 cases in some countries believed to have been “success stories”.

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 8th May) +7.6mln (exp. +4.1mln, prev. +8.4mln). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia is committed to support stability of global oil markets and its cabinet urged OPEC+ countries to adhere to reduced rates to contribute to restoring balance in global oil markets, according to Saudi Press Agency. (Newswires)

CME raised crude oil NYMEX maintenance margins by 20% to USD 12000/contract from USD 10000/contract. (Newswires)

Citi upgraded Q2 average gold price outlook to USD 1710/oz and said its base case market outlook continues to forecast a breach of USD 2000/oz next year, while it expects platinum prices supported through H2 this year on improved economic sentiment and investment demand. (Newswires)

GT citing analyst says China will likely cut LNG imports from Australia, adding that US and Qatar are eyeing Australia's share. (Newswires)

subject: US PRE-MARKET THEMES: Fed Chair Powell before the cash open; bear market rally is over, Nomura says
analysis_details:
SNAPSHOT: Asian equities were mixed overnight, Europe is in the red, although US equity futures have come off overnight lows after the hefty slide in late Tuesday trade (see below for theories). The Treasury curve is biased towards bull-flattening ahead of Powell and long-end supply. The dollar is slightly lower; activity currencies are performing well except for NZD (its central bank doubled QE and hinted at negative rates), the GBP printed ‘better’ than expected GDP. EMFX is mixed, while gold continues to consolidate around USD 1,700. NIH Director Fauci’s cautious comments cap optimism, while traders are cognizant of US/China risks, with talk on Capitol Hill of possible sanctions measures against the Chinese.

POWELL AHEAD (0900 ET/1400 BST): Powell’s remarks are likely to be a reiteration of his post-FOMC comments on 29th April. However, there are a few key themes we will be paying close attention to: negative rates, yield curve control, and fiscal stimulus. We have put together a primer here explaining the nuances of the themes, and how markets are likely to react.

ABOUT LAST NIGHT: The SPX fell in afternoon trade on Tuesday, backed by very little news flow. At the time, Treasuries were stable, as was oil in post-settlement trade, which has led some to suggest that the downside was a result of a chunky sell-side imbalance in thin market conditions; others suggested it was a result of cautious comments from NIH director Fauci, although the timing of the comments and market moves do not coincide. Nevertheless, the downside was not surprising to some, including analysts at Goldman Sachs; earlier in the week, we wrote about why this rally is unloved, and provided Goldman’s six reasons why the market could be in store for downside; 1) COVID infection rates outside of NY continue to rise, and may accelerate as lockdowns are lifted; 2) the restart process will take time; 3) bank loan loss reserves were built in Q1 based on a jobless rate of around 10% - that rate rose to 14.7% in April, and GS forecasts loan loss provisions will need to rise to USD 115bln in the next four quarters (versus total of USD 46bln in Q1); this may weigh on share repurchase/buybacks plans, shaking a key pillar of support that equities have enjoyed in the last decade; 4) dividends are at risk, and are seen falling further this year, as too are capex plans; 5) tax policy risk around elections; tax reforms in 2017 lowered corporation tax to 18% from 26%, and may become a political issue; 6) US/China risks, a headwind in 2019, are resurfacing.

END OF BEAR MARKET RALLY: Nomura's quants think the bear market rally in equities has run its course, and we will now see a temporary market cool-down, as catalysts for a swing to genuine bullishness seem to be lacking, and stock market sentiment in the US is tracking its median recovery trajectory that it has historically seen after steep falls. Another reason Nomura offers is due to the way CTAs have started selling equity futures globally; its model shows CTAs cutting longs in S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures, and for the latter, the trigger line appears to be around 8,450, Nomura says. The model also suggests CTAs have growing shorts in Russell 2000 and Dow Jones futures. The bank suggests that there has been little FOMO from global macro hedge funds too in the latest rally, with these funds seeing opportunities for short-covering. "We therefore think that chain-reaction selling of the sort that would pull DM equity markets down sharply looks unlikely," it caveats.

DRUCKENMILLER: Influential investor Stan Druckenmiller delivered sobering comments to the Economic Club of NY aftermarket on Tuesday, suggesting that the risk-reward for equities was as bad as he's ever seen it in his career, and stocks were historically overvalued. He also argued that markets were overreacting to the progress of anti COVID treatments. Druckenmiller also does not buy into the theory that the Fed has the market's back (i.e. has backstopped the downside), and argued that what we were seeing is not capitalism. He also warned of bankruptcies ahead, in addition to more regulation and higher taxes ahead due to COVID.

LONG-END SUPPLY: A more significant concession might be appropriate for today’s 30-year auction, relative to the 10-year supply, BMO believes, noting within the 1.35-1.40% range, the 30-year sector has continued to underperform the balance of the curve, which has led to re-steepening particularly in 2s10s and 5s30s; BMO believes more steepening could be in store as a result of the front-end of the curve being anchored to monetary policy expectations, and the second wave of steepening is likely to occur when evidence of upward pressure on inflation is seen; for the time being, the probability of inflation expectations spiking any time soon is limited. Preview here.
